children.name: famous a1
children.definition: famous famous people, places, books etc are known about and talked about by a lot of people in a lot of places: nổi tiếng
examples: a famous actor
many famous people have stayed in the hotel.
the eiffel tower is afamous landmark(= a famous place or building that is easy to recognize ).
famous for
france is famous for its wine.
famous as
virginia is famous as the birthplace of several us presidents.
world-famousfamous all over the world nổi tiếng thế giới
rio’s world-famous carnival
da vinci’sworld-famousportrait of the mona lisa
the famous[p] people who are famous :
a nightclub used bythe rich and famous
the rich and famous[p] people who are rich and famous:
the night club is popular among the rich and famous.

children.name: well known a2
children.definition: well-known/well known known about by a lot of people, especially in a particular place: được biết đến
examples: she works in local radio, and is quite well known in the houston area.
large companies have an advantage because of their well-known brand names.
it is well-known (that)
it’s a well-known fact that smoking can cause lung cancer.
this is probably their best-known song.
a well-known tv presenter
well-known for
he was well-known for his extreme political views.
better-known/best-knownđược biết đến rộng rãi
▪ pat boone is one of america’s best-known christian entertainers.

children.name: legendary c1
children.definition: legendary very famous and greatly admired – used especially about people who have been doing sth for a long time or who have died : lừng danh, thần kỳ, “truyền thuyết”
examples: the studio was owned by sam goldwyn, the legendary hollywood producer.
the album was recorded at the legendary abbey road studios.
the legendary blues guitarist, bb king
her stage performances were legendary.

children.name: celebrated x
children.definition: celebratedwrittenvery well known, admired, and talked about by a lot of people, especially because of some special success or achievement: lừng danh
examples: ▪ martin luther king jr. gave his celebrated speech before the lincoln memorial in 1963.
▪ van gogh, perhaps holland’s most celebrated artist, died in poverty.

children.name: noted x
children.definition: notednoted musician/scientist/surgeon etcwell known and respected because of a special ability or achievement.notedis more formal thanrenowned:nổi tiếng, danh tiếng
examples: the picture was taken in the mid-1880s by the noted photographer c.s. fly.
the author quotes stephen jay gould, the noted harvard scientist, to support his theories.

children.name: renowned c2
children.definition: renowned known and admired by a lot of people, especially for a special skill, achievement, or quality: trứ danh
examples: jesse jackson, the renowned civil rights leader, was in the city again last night.
aninternationally renownedchef owns the restaurant.
renowned author/actor/photographer etc
a world renowned expert in the field
renowned for
an island renowned for its beauty
renowned as
he’s renowned as a brilliant speaker.

children.name: eminent c2
children.definition: eminentan eminent doctor, lawyer, scientist etcis famous for being extremely successful in his or her profession and is admired and respected for this: kiệt xuất, lỗi lạc, xuất chúng
examples: she’s an eminent psychiatrist at the harvard medical school.
while he lived, nehru remained the most eminent spokesman for the third world.

children.name: become famous a1
children.definition: become famous/well known/bɪˌkʌm ˈfeɪməs, wel ˈnəʊn/  nổi tiếng
examples: ▪ many people dream of becoming famous.
▪ the brand name has become well known in britain through clever advertising.
become famous overnightvery suddenly : nổi tiếng trong một sớm một chiều
▪ with the success of their first record, they became famous overnight.

children.name: become well known a2
children.definition: become famous/well known/bɪˌkʌm ˈfeɪməs, wel ˈnəʊn/  nổi tiếng
examples: ▪ many people dream of becoming famous.
▪ the brand name has become well known in britain through clever advertising.
become famous overnightvery suddenly : nổi tiếng trong một sớm một chiều
▪ with the success of their first record, they became famous overnight.

children.name: make your name c2
children.definition: make your name/make a name for yourself/ˌmeɪk jɔːʳ ˈneɪm, ˌmeɪk ə ˈneɪm fər jɔːʳself/  to become well known, especially as a result of hard work or an unusual achievement:
examples: tạo lên tên tuổi
▪ clint eastwood first made a name for himself in the tv series ‘rawhide’.
make your name/make a name for yourself as tạo nên tên tuổi như là
▪ by the time he was 30, evans had made his name as the editor of ‘the sunday times’.
▪ she is beginning to make a name for herself as a fashion designer.

children.name: rise to fame x
children.definition: rise to fame/shoot to fame/win fame (as) to become famous, especially suddenly: ngôi sao mới nổi
examples: ▪ john lydon shot to fame in the mid-1970s as johnny rotten of the sex pistols.
▪ she won fame as the youngest-ever olympic champion gymnast.
rise to fame[noun phrase]
▪ the movie focuses on stern’s rise to fame.

children.name: achieve notoriety x
children.definition: achieve notoriety to become famous for sth bad: đạt được tai tiếng
examples: ▪ the director’s films have achieved notoriety for their graphic depiction of violence.
achieve a certain notorietybecome slightly famous for something đạt được tai tiếng
▪ the club has achieved a certain notoriety as a meeting place for criminals and drug dealers.

children.name: hit the headlines x
children.definition: hit the headlines/make (the) headlines/ˌhɪt ðə ˈhedlaɪnz, ˌmeɪk (ðə) ˈhedlaɪnz/  to suddenly become very famous and receive a lot of attention from the newspapers, television etc, sometimes only for a short time: trang đầu
examples: ▪ the island hit the headlines last year when huge tidal waves killed 2,000 people.
▪ the bizarre court case was shown on tv and made headlines around the world.

children.name: rising star x
children.definition: rising star someone, especially a young person, who is quickly becoming more and more famous: ngôi sao đang lên
examples: ▪ she’s one of the rising stars of politics and an excellent public speaker.

children.name: all-star x
children.definition: all-star including many famous actors, sports players etc : toàn sao
examples: an all-star baseball team
the video performance with all-star backup singers was a bit odd.
since then we've done all-star performances in london with sixty-five colleges.
an all-star cast
his latest film featured an all-starcast.
it's a contemporary version with an a less than all-star cast.

children.name: star a2
children.definition: star a very famous and successful actor, entertainer, or sports player: ngôi sao
examples: hollings’ latest movie role could make her a big star.
a big star(= a very famous and successful star )he has worked with some of the world’s biggest stars.
a movie/hollywood star(alsoa film starespecially british english)he looked like a movie star.
a pop/rock starwho’s your favourite pop star?
a tv starmost tv stars do quite a lot of charity work.
a soap star(= a star in a television soap opera )she was known as a soap star before she took up singing.
a sports/football/basketball etc starsam was a football star in college.
an international star(= a star who is famous in many countries )his performance in 'the titanic' made him an international star.
a rising star(= someone who is becoming famous and successful )she is very much the rising star of black american fiction.
a child star(= a child who is a famous performer )the production team say they have been careful to look after all their child stars.
star quality(= a special quality that could make someone a star )she radiates genuine star quality.
star treatment(= special treatment that a star gets )winners get star treatment from the media.
a star vehicle(= a film or television programme that is intended to show the abilities of one particular star )he denied that the movie was just a star vehicle for tom hanks.
a star of stage and screen(= a star who has been in plays and films )now this much-loved star of stage and screen has been made a dame.

children.name: name x
children.definition: name a famous person whose name is known by many people – used especially in the following expressions :
examples: giorgio armani is one of the mostfamous namesin fashion.
big nameinformal a famous and successful performer: tên tuổi lớn
all the big names in football were at the awards dinner.
eric hawkins, one of the big names of modern american dance
household namea person, company, or product that is a household name is so famous that everyone knows their name: cái tên thân thuộc
he is yet to become a household name(= someone who everyone has heard of ).
coca-cola is a household name all over the world.
make sb/sth a household name
ralph nader’s consumer activism has made him a household name in the u.s.
big-name[adj] tên tuổi lớn
the stadium has managed to attract a number of big-name entertainers.

children.name: celebrity b1
children.definition: celebrity/celebinformal  sb who is well known, for example as an entertainer or sports player, and who is often seen on television or written about in newspapers.celebritiesare often famous for being famous, not because they have any great talent: người nổi tiếng
examples: people waited outside for the chance to see some celebrities.
the bar is a good place to go if you want to spot some celebs.
tv/showbusiness/media etc celebrity
the club is popular with media celebrities and literary types.
celebrity interview/photograph/biography etc
mattie reads mainly tabloids and celebrity biographies.
celebrity golf tournament/game showin which celebrities take part giải golf, chương trình trò chơi cùng các nghệ sĩ
nash played in a celebrity golf tournament while in canada.
minor celebritynot extremely famous, popular, or successful
six minor celebrities took part in the charity ‘big brother’ programme.

children.name: personality b2
children.definition: personality someone who is very famous and often appears in the newspapers, on television etc, especially an entertainer or sports person: người nổi tiếng
examples: for years she was one of the best-loved personalities in the newspaper gossip columns.
tv/radio/sports etc personality nhân vật tv, radio, thể thao
radio personality don imus has gotten in trouble again for what he said on the air.
one of the most well-liked tv personalities

children.name: fame b2
children.definition: fame the state of being known about by a lot of people because of your achievements : tiếng tăm, danh vọng
examples: he claims he is not really interested in fame.
of television/movie/baseball etc fame(= used to show what someone is famous for )
the book is about bonnie parker of bonnie and clyde fame.
muhammad ali, of boxing fame
at the height of sb’s famewhen sb is most famous : ở đỉnh cao của danh vọng
at the height of his fame, it is estimated that 500 million people watched his show.
win/gain famehe won fame when he appeared in the film ‘the graduate’.
achieve/find fameamy johnson found fame as a pilot.
bring/win somebody/something famechomsky’s theories about language brought him fame.
rise to fame(= become famous )she rose to fame during the early sixties.
shoot to fame(= become famous very suddenly )she shot to fame as a result of her victory in the olympics.
seek fame(= try to become famous )he sought fame in the jazz clubs of new york.
enjoy fame(= be famous )the town briefly enjoyed fame as the location of a popular television series.
international/worldwide fameedinburgh achieved international fame as a centre of medical education.
national fameher oil paintings won her national fame.
lasting fame(= being famous for a long time )diderot gained lasting fame as the editor of the french encyclopaedia.
brief fame(= being famous for a short time )ed achieved brief fame as a pop singer in the late 1980s.
instant famethe success of her first novel brought her instant fame.
great famehis acting ability brought him great fame.
new-found fameanna was finding it difficult to get used to her new-found fame.
sb’s/sth’s rise to fameher rise to fame has been astonishingly rapid.
at the height of sb’s/sth’s fame(= when someone was most famous )at the height of his fame, he could earn $5,000 a day.
sb’s/sth’s claim to fame(= reason for being famous )one of his main claims to fame is having invented the electric light bulb.
fame and fortune(= being rich and famous )he came to london to seek fame and fortune.

children.name: stardom c2
children.definition: stardom when sb is very famous, especially in music, films, or sport: địa vị ngôi sao
examples: stardom is the ultimate ambition of most young singers and actors.
she feared that by having a baby she had sacrificed her chances of stardom.
his rapid rise to stardom
shoot/rise/zoom to stardom(= become famous very quickly )
ellen shot to stardom as a model last year.

children.name: renown x
children.definition: renownformalwrittenfame and admiration that sb has because of sth good such as great skill, knowledge, or bravery: danh tiếng
examples: the general’s victories won him renown throughout the country.
international/public etc renown
he haswonworldrenownfor his films.
heachievedsomerenownas a football player.
of great/international/high etc renown
speakers of international renown will attend the conference.

children.name: unknown b1
children.definition: unknown not at all famous: không được biết đến, vô danh
examples: ▪ as an unknown author, it isn’t easy to get your work published.
▪ horn was beaten by a relatively unknown politician in the last election.
unknown[c] vô danh
▪ a movie made with a cast of complete unknowns

children.name: a nobody x
children.definition: a nobody sb who is very ordinary and not at all famous or important: người tầm thường
examples: ▪ after all her hard work, she didn’t want to end up just a nobody.
▪ a lot of the rich people who come in here treat us like nobodies.

children.name: obscure x
children.definition: obscure sb/sth that is obscure is known about only by a few people, because they belong to a group, place, or subject that not many people know about or are interested in: không tiếng tăm
examples: ▪ he’s using an obscure old law to try to stop the new road being built.
▪ the lines were written by an obscure english poet named mordaunt.
obscurity[u]
▪ after the accident he retired from acting and died in relative obscurity.

children.name: receiving a lot of attention in newspapers etc
be in the public eye c1
children.definition: be in the public eye/biː ɪn ðə ˌpʌblɪk ˈaɪ/  to receive a lot of attention, so that a lot of what you do is reported in newspapers, on television etc: ở giữa sự chú ý
examples: ▪ the president’s family is constantly in the public eye.
▪ marks has kept himself in the public eye for years by filing bizarre lawsuits.

children.name: be in the spotlight c2
children.definition: be in the spotlight/limelight/biː ɪn ðə ˈspɒtlaɪt, ˈlaɪmlaɪtǁ-ˈspɑːt-/  to receive a lot of attention in newspapers, on television etc, but often only for a short period of time: trung tâm dư luận
examples: ▪ the band is in the spotlight again because of its recent hit single.
▪ how do her children feel about having a mother who’s constantly in the limelight?

children.name: most talked about u
children.definition: much/most talked about/ˌmʌtʃ, ˌməʊst ˈtɔːkt əbaʊt/  receiving a lot of attention from newspapers, television etc, and talked about by a lot of people: thường được nhắc đến
examples: ▪ the much talked about new museum is somewhat disappointing.
▪ she is australia’s most talked about tv actress.

children.name: sb’s name is on everyone’s lips x
children.definition: somebody’s name is on everyone’s lips/ somebodyˈs ˌneɪm ɪz ɒn ˌevriwʌnz ˈlɪps/ if someone’s name is on everyone’s lips they are very well known and talked about for a short time, usually as a result of a news story: được nhắc đến dạo này
examples: ▪ as a result of the scandal, the tall texan millionaire’s name was on everyone’s lips.

children.name: high-profile c2
children.definition: high-profile/ˌhaɪ ˈprəʊfaɪl◂/  often attracting a lot of attention because of your position in society or your job: nổi danh
examples: ▪ a high-profile civil rights lawyer
▪ a high-profile position as chief executive

children.name: notorious c1
children.definition: notorious famous because of doing something bad: khét tiếng
examples: one of britain’s most notorious criminals has escaped from prison.
davis is a notorious woman-hater.
a notorious criminal
a notorious legal case
notorious for
english soccer fans are notorious for their drunkenness.

children.name: infamous x
children.definition: infamous famous for being bad, especially for being immoral or evil: khét tiếng
examples: he was a member of the regime’s infamous secret police.
the night club is named after new orleans’ infamous red light district.
an infamous killer
los angeles’ infamous smog
infamous for
this area is infamous for drugs and prostitution.

children.name: superstar x
children.definition: superstar an actor, musician, or sports player who is extremely famous all over the world:
examples: the film made tom cruise an international superstar.
janet jackson became a superstar largely because of her exciting music videos.
radio/tv/basketball etc superstar ngôi sao radio, tv, bóng rổ thế giới
hockey superstar wayne gretzky played for l.a. before retiring.

children.name: legend c1
children.definition: legend sb who is famous and admired for being extremely good at doing sth – used especially about people who are at the end of a long career or who have died: huyền thoại
examples: among mexican music fans, fernandez is a legend.
a marvellous player who wasa legend inhisown lifetime
living legendin somebody’s own lifetime someone who has become a legend while still alive huyền thoại sống
michael jordan is a living legend of basketball.
tennis/footballing/music etc legend
we must put more money into the sport if we want to create the tennis legends of the future.

children.name: great x
children.definition: great sb who was one of the best players or performers that there have ever been : vĩ đại
examples: he was one of the all-time soccer greats.
jack nicklaus is one of golf’sall-time greats.
i think his show’s ok, but i wouldn’t call him one of the greats.

children.name: icon b2
children.definition: iconsb famous who is admired by many people and is thought to represent an important idea:thần tượng
examples: a sixties cultural icon
marilyn monroe and james dean are still icons for many young people.
